abstract: We report preliminary data from a cohort of adults admitted to COVID-designated intensive care units from March 6 through April 17, 2020 across an academic healthcare system. Among 217 critically ill patients, mortality for those who required mechanical ventilation was 29.7% (49/165), with 8.5% (14/165) of patients still on the ventilator at the time of this report. Overall mortality to date in this critically ill cohort is 25.8% (56/217), and 40.1% (87/217) patients have survived to hospital discharge. Despite multiple reports of mortality rates exceeding 50% among critically ill adults with COVID-19, particularly among those requiring mechanical ventilation, our early experience indicates that many patients survive their critical illness.
author: Max W. Adelman; Colleen S. Kraft; James M. Blum; Craig S. Jabaley; David Carpenter; Gregory S. Martin; David J. Murphy; Craig M. Coopersmith; Emory COVID-19 Quality and Clinical Research Collaborative; Alfonso C. Hernandez; Jesse T. Jacob; Sara Auld; Roberta Kaplow; Mark Caridi-Scheible; Chad J. Robichaux
title: ICU and ventilator mortality among critically ill adults with COVID-19

funding.funding-statement: This work was supported by the following grants: NIH/NIAID K23 AI134182 (SCA), NIH/CTSA UL1TR002378
